campaign.story:
Open-source machine vision finally ready for prime-time in all your projects!
JeVois = video sensor + quad-core CPU + USB video + serial port, all in a tiny, self-contained package (28 cc or 1.7 cubic inches). Insert a microSD card loaded with the provided open-source machine vision algorithms (including OpenCV 3.2 and many others), connect to your desktop, laptop, and/or Arduino, and give your projects the sense of sight immediately.
JeVois started as an educational project, to encourage the study of machine vision, computational neuroscience, and machine learning as part of introductory programming and robotics courses at all levels (from K-12 to Ph.D.). At present, these courses often lack a machine vision component. This is mainly, we believe, because there is no simple machine vision device one can use together with the Raspberry Pi, Arduino, or similar device used in these courses. JeVois aims to fill this gap by providing a self-contained, configurable machine vision engine that can deliver both visual outputs of how it is analyzing what it sees (useful to understand the algorithms), and text outputs over a serial link that describe what it has found (useful to send to a micro-controller that can control a robot).
Overview
The JeVois framework operates as follows: video is captured from the camera sensor, processed on the fly through some machine vision algorithm directly on the camera's own processor, and the results are streamed over USB to a host computer and/or over serial to a micro-controller.
To the host computer, the JeVois smart camera is just another USB camera. Different vision algorithms are selected by changing USB camera resolution and framerate. Users or machines can also interact with the JeVois smart camera, change its settings, or listen for text-based vision outputs over serial link (both hardware serial and serial-over-USB are supported).
Three major modes of operation:
Demo/development mode: the smart camera outputs a demo display over USB that shows the results of its analysis, possibly along with simple results communicated over serial port (e.g., coordinates and content of any QRcode that has been identified).
Text-only mode: the smart camera provides no USB output, but only text strings, for example, commands for a pan/tilt controller.
Pre-processing mode: the smart camera outputs video that is intended for machine consumption, for example an edge map computed over the video frames captured by the camera sensor, or a set of image crops around the 3 most interesting objects in the scene. This video can then be further processed by the host computer, for example, using a massive deep neural network running on a cluster of high-power GPUs to recognize the three most interesting objects that the smart camera has detected. Text outputs over serial are of course also possible in this mode.
But, really, anything is possible, since the whole JeVois software framework is open-source.
Hardware Specs
At a glance:
 A brief tour:
The JeVois smart camera is a complete Linux computer. It can run on its own, without a host PC. Thanks to the cooling fan, it can run under full processing load without overheating and while maintaining a constant 1.34 GHz CPU speed.
 Software Specs
A few examples (watch the video for more). All results shown below are computed on the JeVois camera itself. The smart camera does all the work, including image capture, vision processing, and creating the demo displays. The host computer only runs a standard video camera software (e.g., guvcview on a Linux host) to display the smart camera's results.
Visual Attention detects interesting things in the world
 In the above, the algorithm processing speed is 73.1 fps on the smart camera's processor, that is, it takes 13.68 ms to process one video frame. The camera sensor captures frames at 60 fps (16.67 ms per frame), which sets the video streaming speed. One could run some additional algorithms during the 3 ms difference. Also note that the CPU is not fully loaded by this algorithm (148.7% load, while 400% would correspond to fully loading all 4 CPU cores). Hence additional algorithms could also run in parallel with visual attention.
Augmented reality markers (ArUco)
  Object detection and recognition
  Road detection for autonomous driving
  120Hz eye tracking (camera streams at 120 fps, processing runs at 200+ fps)
and see many more in the campaign video.
This is an open-source project. Anyone can contribute. Which vision algorithms will you create?
Host Computer Requirements
The JeVois smart camera can work as a standalone computer, with no USB video streaming. In such case, one would usually simply stream commands to an Arduino or similar over the serial port. All you need then is to provide power to the JeVois camera's mini-USB connector.
For video streaming over USB:
Linux (including Raspberry Pi): Works out of the box, no drivers needed, all functionality is available. You can switch between different vision processing modes on the fly and at runtime, by selecting different camera resolutions and frame rates on your host computer. For example, 640x300@60fps may run the visual attention algorithm, while 320x256@60fps may run the QRcode detection algorithm. A configuration file on the MicroSD card establishes the mapping between USB video resolution and frame rate, camera sensor resolution and frame rate, and vision algorithm to run.
Windows, Mac OS X: Streaming works but selecting among different available video resolutions has become increasingly difficult with newer versions of Windows and OS X. It seems that these operating systems do not want to let you choose a camera resolution or frame rate. This choice, however, is how one can switch on the fly between different vision algorithms on the JeVois camera. One workaround is to configure your JeVois smart camera with only one vision algorithm (achieved by commenting out entries for other resolutions in a configuration file on the MicroSD card). Then the host computer will have no choice but to use that one.
Android: The camera is detected but streaming video does not work yet. We are working on this and we suspect this has to do with deviations from the USB video class (UVC) standard on the Android side. For example, a USB packet sniffer has revealed that the Android device insists on querying camera controls that were not declared as being supported by the JeVois hardware.
iOS: The JeVois smart camera, and any other USB camera we have tried, are currently reported as not being a supported device. This may change in the future.
Connecting to Arduino or similar
Developing for JeVois
Everything is cross-compiled on a host computer. At present only Linux is supported for compiling JeVois software. JeVois software is written in C++17, with a few low-level algorithms in optimized C. We use CMake to manage the build process. This allows you to build for both your host computer and for the JeVois hardware, both at the same time. This is very useful during development, since you can test your algorithms using any USB webcam and observe the results in a window on your screen. You can also use your host computer to train a deep neural network quickly, and then just load the weights onto your MicroSD card. The JeVois operating system is Linux and its features are managed by buildroot.
Scripts are provided to automate the process:
rebuild-host.sh - compile the entire JeVois software suite natively on a host computer. You can use it with a USB webcam, and it display outputs in a window on your screen.
rebuild-platform.sh - cross-compile the entire JeVois software suite for the smart camera hardware.
jevois-build.sh - flash the cross-compiled results from rebuild-platform.sh to a MicroSD card.
Contributions & novelty
In principle, you could assemble a working machine vision system using existing embedded computer boards, adding a camera, and programming a USB output. In fact, this how we started... - er, two years ago!
The hurdles we encountered and solved in creating JeVois are as follows:
- Linux support for camera chips is often very limited. We wrote our own highly efficient kernel driver and figured out how to configure undocumented camera chip registers to support all the controls available on the camera (exposure, frame rate, etc). Most camera drivers in the Linux kernel only support one or a few resolutions and frame rates, many do not support controls such as manual exposure, etc. You could use a USB camera, for which support for the controls has been standardized, but not many support 60 or 120 frames/s, and they would increase the overall size, weight, power and cost of the system. Our kernel camera driver exploits hardware that is integrated into our CPU chip for direct image capture from a camera sensor. This is faster, provides lower latency (time between image capture and start of rocessing), and uses less CPU resources than attaching a USB camera sensor.
- Linux support for the device-side of video streaming over USB is virtually non-existent (in open source). This is software that you need to run on the smart camera's CPU to make it appear as if it was a USB camera to a connected host computer. A webcam gadget module has been present in the Linux kernel source tree for several years, but its functionality is very limited, and, as we discovered, its very core logic is broken. We developed a fully working device-side kernel USB Video Class driver, with highly efficient data streaming and pass-through support for video resolutions, pixel formats, frame rates, and camera controls (when users change those on the host computer, the changes are relayed to the camera sensor chip).
- Many small embedded computer boards exist, but software support is often limited, and quality sometimes is low. We had to fix kernel USB drivers, kernel GPU drivers, kernel camera drivers, and many other elements in the Linux kernel to make it work flawlessly while supporting all the features listed above. Small embedded boards also are no match for our solution in terms of total system size (including camera, connectors, fan), power consumption, speed and video latency (delay between capturing an image and presenting the processing results to the host computer), and out-of-the box enjoyment and reliability. For example, one has to face the reality that a quad-core chip will just overheat under load if it does not have a fan or very, very large heatsink.
We employed special design and manufacturing techniques which enabled us to deliver a complete, self-contained system in a tiny form factor. As an example, we run our DDR3 memory at its full rated clock speed (DDR3-1600), while other ARM boards we have surveyed on the market sometimes run at just half that speed. We achieved optimum speed as the result of extremely detailed circuit board design and optimization, and through the use of custom design, simulation, and fabrication tools. It makes a big difference for many vision processing algorithms (about 15% faster).
In summary, because we are developing the hardware, software and mechanical design jointly, we are able to deliver a highly optimized, plug-and-play, high satisfaction solution that just does not exist anywhere else today.
Long-Term Vision
With JeVois we aim to enable everyone to use machine vision in embedded, IoT, robotics, and educational projects. While this campaign is to help us bootstrap the mass manufacturing of the hardware, we continue to work on the following open-source software aspects:
Software development is gearing up to provide a repository of machine vision modules shared by the community. This is the equivalent of an app store for JeVois. It is expected to come online by February, before the devices start shipping.
We are developing a curriculum of activities around the JeVois camera for all levels (from kindergarten to Ph.D.). Activities will start at the entry level (just point the camera towards something and see whether it can identify it), to learning how the underlying machine vision algorithms work, to modifying existing algorithms, and finally learning vision theory and developing your own algorithms. This is expected to become available in April. We will leverage significant material we have developed by teaching robotics, vision, and artificial intelligence courses at the undergraduate and graduate level over the past 15 years.
Our overall mission is an educational and outreach one. We hope that JeVois will help us and others translate the latest vision research results into working machines. JeVois will be integrated to our outreach activities, which include working with neighboring K-12 schools, our Robotics Open House program, and others. We have a small budget already available for outreach, which includes loaning and donating some JeVois hardware to interested students. Details will be available in February.
Comparison to the Raspberri Pi 3 model B
Rewards
Rewards include barebones kits and turnkey kits in several quantities. Choose a barebones kit if you already have microSD cards and mini-USB cables and do not need more of those. Choos a turnkey kit if you want to be ready to run out the box.
Colors
Choose your colors in the backer survey after you place your pledge. Note that with the lighter colors, you will see the LED shine through the plastic case and make a small halo around the hole in the case for the LED. You may want this for better visibility or not if you find it distracting. The color that makes the most sense from a machine vision standpoint is black.
Thanks
This campaign is basically to build a batch of units that achieves low mass production costs. Please help us spread the word if you like this project. Thanks!
The science behind JeVois was in part made possible by research grants from the National Science Foundation (NSF) and the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) .
The views, opinions, and findings contained in this presentation are those of the authors and should not be interpreted as representing the official views or policies, either expressed or implied, of the United States government or any agency thereof.
Raspberry Pi is a trademark of the Raspberry Pi Foundation. Arduino is a trademark of Arduino LLC. Windows is a trademark of Microsoft Corporation in the United States and/or other countries. Mac, OS X and iOS are trademarks of Apple Inc., registered in the U.S. and other countries. Android is a trademark of Google Inc.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We just received CE, FCC, and RoHS certification. We also received our first samples from our injection molding partner and they are great (shown in the video).

The main remaining challenges are mass sourcing of the components (i.e., avoiding shortages of some parts), and possible export or custom issues when shipping to foreign countries. We are working on addressing those by securing multiple component sources and by working with international shipping experts.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: JeVois Inventor beta released - new graphical front-end for JeVois
updates.update_content: JeVois Inventor is a graphical front-end for JeVois Smart Cameras. It makes programming new computer vision pipelines that run on JeVois very easy, using full Python 3.6 + OpenCV 3.4.

updates.update_userinfo: JeVois 1.8.0 released with real-time TensorFlow deep networks
updates.update_content:
JeVois 1.8.0 released with TensorFlow support and more. Includes mobile-optimized TensorFlow Lite, which allows one to run TensorFlow deep neural networks on JeVois.
See TensorFlowSingle, TensorFlowSaliency, and TensorFlowEasy for example modules using compressed mobilenet pre-trained networks that can recognize 1000 different object categories at up to 83 inferences/s on JeVois. See more details.

updates.update_userinfo: JeVois and Prof Itti selected by ARM as one of 10 worldwide for new ARM Innovators program!
updates.update_content:
Just announced:
"With over 100 billion processors shipped since 1991, the Arm ecosystem consists of a vast number of talented individuals solving problems in every imaginable domain. Arm Innovators are technical leaders helping to extend Arm architecture and sharing their experience in a wide variety of exciting areas"

updates.update_userinfo: JeVois 1.5.2 with new Darknet+Saliency module, dynamic network resizing
updates.update_content:
A few quick updates with the latest developments at JeVois.org:
Saliency + Darknet: Detect the most interesting (salient) object in the scene, then recognize it using a deep neural network. Saliency detection runs at 15 frames/s at 320x240 or 10 frames/s at 640x480 (limited to not consume too much CPU, saliency can actually run alone at 60+ frames/s at 320x240), and neural network recognition (1000 possible object categories) runs at about 200ms/object (about 5 objects/s). See DarknetSaliency Module.

updates.update_userinfo: JeVois 1.5 released with OpenCV 3.3, latest deep neural networks, and many other latest software packages.
updates.update_content:
Just in case some of you here are not following us yet at http://jevois.org, many exciting new developments with JeVois lately:
- JeVois is now updated to buildroot 2017.08 and includes OpenCV 3.3.0, python 3.6, boost 1.64, eigen 3.3.3, latest tiny-dnn and darknet-nnpack deep neural networks, and many other latest package versions.
- Very powerful object recognition using deep neural networks that run directly on the small embedded processor inside the JeVois camera. Identify objects shown to JeVois (among 1000 possible object categories) using Darknet deep neural networks (a great, small footprint and hardware-accelerated alternative to more resource-hungry deep learning packages like Caffe, Tensorflow, MxNet, PyTorch, etc). Check out the video here:

updates.update_userinfo: JeVois 1.1 released: live access to microSD over USB, Python 3.5+Python-OpenCV, better SDK
updates.update_content:
JeVois 1.1 released. Download the latest microSD image from http://jevois.org/start to try out these new features:
Access the microSD card inside JeVois live over USB as a virtual USB flash drive. Directly edit config files, add training data, retrieve data recorded by JeVois, or install/update machine vision modules without having to physically take out the card. 
Program machine vision modules in Python 3.5 with full Python-OpenCV 3.2.0 support. Combined with the live access to microSD over USB, edit a machine vision module written in Python directly on the JeVois camera without having to remove the card.

updates.update_userinfo: JeVois 1.1 now with Python 3.5 + Python OpenCV 3.2.0 support, browse MicroSD over USB
updates.update_content:
A quick update with our latest developments. This is still in beta (branch dev1.1 on GitHub) but will be released in a few days:
Added support to export the microSD card inside JeVois as a virtual USB flash drive
It was tough and has required quite a bit of Linux kernel hacking and fooling around with our trusty LeCroy USB packet sniffer to get the bugs out, but it seems to be working flawlessly with Windows, Mac, and Linux hosts now. This means that you can now directly edit config files, install new machine vision modules, copy training data for your modules, etc to JeVois without ejecting the microSD card and while JeVois is running. There is no slowing down of the video even when you copy large files to microSD because the video stream is allocated a reserved bandwidth on the USB bus (isochronous).

Greetings all backers -
We shipped in the past few days about 20 extra packages from Los Angeles to those backers who have sent us a message to creator through Kickstarter indicating that they have not received their reward yet. We are doing this as a courtesy and we are absorbing the cost to shorten your wait, as I know that you are all eager to start using your rewards.
If you have not yet received your reward and did not just receive in the past few days a new email with tracking information from the USA, please

Greetings all backers -
We have received the second production batch. All units have been tested with the burn test twice so this batch should contain 100% working units.
Using these units, we shipped yesterday to the 20 or so last backers for whom we had run out of stock.

Greetings backers of JeVois -
Please check these out:
- latest microSD image at http://jevois.org/start improves image uniformity (less darkening of the image away from the center of the picture) and low-light performance. Please try it and see whether you like it.

campaign.story:
The Sixfab Raspberry Pi IoT Shield Family was made specifically to add connectivity to your IoT projects. You can now connect wherever and whenever without the need for a wifi network or ethernet cables. With our added capabilities, the IoT Shield Family will also work with other devices, not only the Raspberry Pi. This Kickstarter will allow even a beginner to enter the Internet of Things universe easily and efficiently with easy-to-use interfaces and instructions. We've also made all software open source, embracing the maker spirit. 
                                                                       >Use Cases Videos
                       Note: As KickStarter doesn't let you add multiple items to your pledge, we have already sold over 500 Early Birds through those who purchased multiple units. Therefore, our Early Bird units have sold-out.                                                                              
                                                                                                                  Sixfab on Social Media!
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
The Sixfab team is comprised of experienced engineers with many years in the electronics sector. Just a short while ago we successfully crowd funded our Tinylab product and completed delivery to all our backers.

We developed many prototypes to work out bugs and maximize performanse. We've eliminated many issues present in the early versions. We've contacted our current component and PCB manufacturers and they are awaiting our final version. We're confident that we'll quickly resolve any issues that might arise during our current phase of testing with the existing prototypes.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: Just for our backers, please don't forward
updates.update_content:
Hi Everyone,
We had asked for some feedback regarding a high-tech affordable smart home solution on behalf of some of our team members that were developing just such a solution. They're all finished and have asked us to relay this special offer that only you Sixfab backers can enjoy:
Here's the project: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/nodez/nodez-the-latest-tech-in-an-affordable-smart-home

Hello Everyone,
By now almost everyone should have received their shields and all of you should have received a tracking number that lets you track your shipment. If you haven't please let us know (and check your spam folder.) Also, about 10 backers haven't provided any shipping address and we'll give you 2 more weeks to get back to us so we can ship you your shields.
Finally, many had asked about constantly switching out your mobile SIM when using the shields. Not only is this a pain to do but cell phone companies do charge a lot for data.
We think we've found a great solution and are sending it to you, our loyal backer, as a gift. We've included a free Hologram SIM card in your shipment and it comes preloaded with some free data so you can use your shields as soon as the shields arrive, no need to go out and buy a new SIM and get on a new data plan.

updates.update_userinfo: The moment we've all been waiting for...
updates.update_content:
Ok, so maybe that was a little overdramatic... The final shields are being completed and packed as you read this. Look out for tracking information to be sent next week.
Thank you for believing in us and supporting us during this process. We hope you enjoy your shields and will also announce next week a solution to get your shields connected without the need to go out and buy a new sim card and data plan.
Finally here's some riveting footage of the final shields coming off the production line, enjoy!

updates.update_userinfo: In final stage before on-time shipment
updates.update_content:
Hello Everyone,
We've just received our circuit boards (as pictured) and are now in the component placement phase. We hope to have all shields completed by the end of the month and will relay shipment info as the shields ship.
Thank you, The Sixfab Team

updates.update_userinfo: Ship date and Free Surprise Gift
updates.update_content:
Hi All,
There were a few questions about our last update and we wanted to reiterate that we are working hard to ensure and are on track for an on-time ship date of March, 2017. We also wanted to ask for your help in answering a 1 question 10-second survey question:
https://goo.gl/forms/ldC1eOAV3OAS3sL53

Hi everyone!
All designs have been revised and we placed an order for all PCBs and components. 
We hope to start mass production and assembly as soon as possible.
Sixfab Team

Hi Backers,
We're expecting to receive the funds from our Kickstarter this week. You should all have been charged by now (if not, let us know.) As soon as we get the pledges we'll let you know and we'll send out surveys to confirm orders and which countries/carriers you will be using your shields in. We had pledges from 52 countries! We'll then move quickly into production and will keep you updated every step of the way!

We want to sincerely thank everyone for believing in us and backing this project. We will be sending out a survey later this week confirming all orders and details. Please check your email to make sure your pledge was properly processed as there were several pledges that were not able to be processed.
These need to be processed in the next few days or else the pledge will be cancelled and you will miss out on the deep discounts associated with this project.

campaign.story:
12 months ago we launched a Kickstarter campaign for the UP Board, the most powerful credit card sized board powered by Intel Atom x5-Z8350 Quadcore. Just a year later we have successfully brought the UP Board into mass production and delivered it to more than 12,000 different makers in the fields of IOT, Entertainment, Digital signage, Smart Home automation, Robotics, Intelligent vending, Industrial automation and more. Now, we're elated to announce UP² (UP Squared), the most powerful maker board out there.

UP² (UP Squared) is an ultra compact single board computer with high performance and low power consumption. It features the latest Intel® Apollo Lake Celeron™ and Pentium™ Processors with only 4W of Scenario Design Power and a powerful and flexible Intel® FPGA Altera MAX 10 onboard.
Aiming to bridge the gap between makers and industrial markets, the UP team challenged ourselves yet again to bring a cost effective board in x86 architecture by adding some form factor creativity and increasing elements in embedded flavors. Nevertheless, we still hold onto some of the fun as a Maker board with our 40-pin GP-bus. Our ideas transform into a full industrial-featured Maker board, UP² (UP Squared) which starts selling from €89 on Kickstarter

Inheriting the 40-pin GP-bus from the first generation of UP, although this time controlled by Altera FPGA MAX 10, UP² (UP Squared) is powered by Intel® Celeron™ Dual Core N3350 up to 2.4GHz,  Intel® Pentium™ Quad Core N4200 up to 2.5Ghz, or Intel® Atom™ x5-E3940 up to 1.8GHz, up to 8GB of RAM LPDDR4 Dual Channels 64 bit onboard, up to 128 GB onboard eMMC 5.0, more I/O ports including 3 USB 3.0, 2 USB 2.0, 2 Gigabit LAN, 1 HDMI, 1 DP, eDP, mini PCI-e/mini card SATA, M.2 2230, SATA 3.0, 2 CSI and additional 60 pin board-to-board expansion (EXHAT) with GPIO and many other features.  
Latest Intel® Apollo Lake SoC
Intel Apollo Lake is the latest family of Intel Atom™, Celeron™ and Pentium™ Processor with 7 years product longevity. Based on 14nm architecture, Apollo Lake Celeron™, Pentium™  and Atom™  deliver extremely high performances with only 4W of Scenario Design Power ( SDP ) and only 6W of Thermal Design Power ( TDP )*.
* Atom™x5-E3940 TDP 9.5W
The Intel® Pentium™ N4200 is a 64-bit Quad Core processor which runs at a dynamic frequency from 1.1GHz to 2.5 GHz based on the need of the users. It comes with 2MB Cache L2, 64 Bit Dual Channels memory LPDDR4 at 2400MT/s with the support of up to 8GB.  
The Intel Celeron™ N3350 is a 64-bit Dual Core processor which runs at a dynamic frequency from 1.1GHz up to 2.4GHz based on the need of the application. It comes with 2MB Cache L2, 64 Bit Dual Channels memory LPDDR4 at 2400MT/s with the support of up to 8GB.  
The Intel® Atom™ x5-E3940 is a 64-bit Quadl Core processor which runs at a dynamic frequency from 1.6GHz up to 1.8GHz based on the need of the application. It comes with 2MB Cache L2, 64 Bit Dual Channels memory LPDDR4 at 2400MT/s with the support of up to 8GB.
Both CPU’s support the Intel Secure Boot Technology, the Intel® Virtualization Technology (VT-x), Intel® Virtualization Technology for Directed I/O, Intel® VT-x with Extended Page Tables (EPT), Intel® 64, Idle states, Enhanced Intel SpeedStep® Technology, Thermal Monitoring Technologies, Intel® HD Audio Technology, Intel® Identity Protection Technology, Intel® AES New Instructions, Secure Key and Execute Disable Bit.  
CPU Comparison
CPU benchmark by CPU Monkey
  N3350 (MultiCore)
   N4200 (MultiCore)
 Most Powerful GPU 
The Intel® Pentium™ N4200 GPU is one of the most powerful GPU’s that Intel has ever designed. The core is the Intel HD Graphics 505 which runs at base frequency of 200MHz with a graphics burst frequency of 750MHz. The GPU can allocate up to 8GB of RAM and it has 18 Execution Units. It supports Direct X, OpenGL, Intel® Quick Sync Video, Intel® Clear Video HD Technology and up to 3 independent displays. 
The Intel® Celeron™ N3350 GPU is one of the most powerful GPU’s that Intel has ever designed. The core is the Intel HD Graphics 500 which runs at base frequency of 200MHz with a graphics burst frequency of 650MHz. The GPU can allocate up to 8GB of RAM and it has 12 Execution Units. It supports Direct X, OpenGL, Intel® Quick Sync Video, Intel® Clear Video HD Technology and up to 3 independent displays.
The Intel® Atom™ x5-E3940 GPU is one of the most powerful GPU’s that Intel has ever designed. The core is the Intel HD Graphics 500 which runs at base frequency of 400MHz with a graphics burst frequency of 600MHz. The GPU can allocate up to 2GB of RAM and it has 12 Execution Units. It supports Direct X, OpenGL, Intel® Quick Sync Video, Intel® Clear Video HD Technology and up to 3 independent displays.
N3350 iGPU
  N4200 iGPU
   More expansions, more I/O
FPGA 
Once more, we find ourselves moving one step ahead of most maker boards. Instead of a CPLD embedded controller, we decided to integrate FPGA -- Altera Max 10 (2K)  with UP² (UP Squared). FPGA is powerful and permits flexibility in design. Without changing any hardware, the board the board can have different electrical characteristics by loading different firmwares in FPGA.
MAX® 10 devices are single-chip, non-volatile low-cost programmable logic devices (PLDs) to integrate the optimal set of system components. The highlights of the MAX 10 devices include: • Internally stored dual configuration flash • User flash memory • Instant on support • Single-chip Nios II soft core processor support MAX 10 devices are the ideal solution for system management, I/O expansion, communication control planes, industrial, automotive, and consumer applications. 

40-pin GP-bus
Have some fun trying out some of the Raspberry Pi2 modules on UP² (UP Squared)! You can easily explore more possibilities with your project. Whenever we have a new compatibility test, the UP Community will continue to validate and publish all the results we collect.
40-pin GP bus - Raspberry pin layout
60-pin EXHAT
  Click to see detailed pinout
   Operating systems 
UP² (UP Squared) runs many different operating systems like Windows 10, Windows IoT Core, Linux and Android.
Operating System
About our Community, Shop, Aaeon & Asus
Today we have more than 2000 users at UP Community, and we sell our boards and peripherals at UP shop. We would like to invite you to share within UP Community and join our party at UP Shop !
Buy your UP² (UP Squared), HATs, cables and other spare parts on the UP-Shop, learn from UP-community, share the projects with all the UP makers and - once you are ready – publish your project onto the Intel Solution Finder. and Sell your product via UP Shop and via UP’s Resellers Partners. UP² (UP Squared) turns your great ideas into real business.
Are you looking for a customization service? Yes,We can gladly assist you with that too ! Yes, AAEON is an associate company owned by Asus, and we are ready to take care of your customization requirements.
AAEON custom service
UP Eco-system 
UP² (UP Squared) is building further on the maturity of the original UP board. This means that the Eco-system is already actively developing software and hardware for the upcoming UP² system. Whether you are working in industrial automation, vending, digital signage, IoT, Home automation or robotics; there are have been talented people laying down the foundation for your project.  
Some examples of our cooperations are:
Intel RealSense (robotics)
Lora (IoT gateway)
HMS (Industrial Automation)
EnOcean (Home Automation)
TP Link (WiFi functionality)
Markets
Media & Entertainment: KODI
 Intelligent Vending: UP Brainy Solution 
 Robotics & Done: Intel RealSense
 Digital Signage
 Internet of Things: LoRA 
Home Automation
 Industrial Automation
Project status
Now and next--At the beginning of October, we had our first engineering sample. The board is booting successfully and loaded with FPGA firmware. We are in the process of running more function tests and carrying out debug. We expect our second version during mid November. We anticipate to enter the next design phase after debugging the current one as well as optimising performance. Parallel to this we will validate Windows 10 and Ubilinux Debian first. Thereafter we will focus on Ubuntu, Yocto, Windows IoT Core and Android. 
PLAY

UP v.s. UP²
  Rewards
Project plan
   UP^2 timeline
   UP TEAM
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
Following on from our very first Kickstarter project we've come a long way and learnt a lot too! Thermal design and the step up to x5-Z8350 delayed the UP Board project. With the next generation UP² (UP Squared), we are taking a different path on thermal design, using all our knowledge gained from UP. 

With UP² (UP Squared) we have spent more than two months discussing all specifications and component placement. We've driven all product capabilities in once, therefore we remain confident that no more upgrade options need to be managed later on. We've brought together a logistic team in-house, this will assist us in providing a delivery plan and handle all orders efficiently!

We had to work with LPDDR4 technology for the first time together with a complete new architecture that hasn’t reached the market yet. Just a few days back, we amended the design to enhance the memory bandwidth. Now, we are working on developing the drivers for Altera FPGA MAX 10 to control the 40 Pin I/O as well as the 60 Pin. We are also improving layout optimixations and eMMC firmware boot.

UP² (UP Squared) is the answer to all applications.
.
Are you up for UP² (UP Squared) ? Hurry UP! and reserve your UP² (UP Squared) right here now!
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hi guys,
It has been a while since UP Squared was introduced. Thanks to your support, we are doing all fine. In fact, UP Squared was selected by Intel as IoT and AI development platform. We got more and more requests to make it more industrialized. 
We are thinking to bring a new UP Squared to you by adding on something we missed and removing something you didn't need.

updates.update_userinfo: Latest - Delivery of E3940 to all Kickstarter backers
updates.update_content:
Dear all
We have been trying our level best to release shipment of E3940 but unfortunately we have to apologize for the delay again. The board was produced 2 weeks ago and we have waited for software validation to release the shipment. However, we've noticed the ADC function is not fully validated in BIOS and there is a flickering problem in the HDMI output. 
 We’ve been working on this issue and are waiting for a solution from Intel about the  flickering problem. With the E3940, it seems that the flickering is happening in either the display port or HDMI. We find this to be quite unusual after we have dealt with the video output on N4200 and N3350.

updates.update_userinfo: Delivery of E3940 to all Kickstarter backers_update
Kickstarter orders will be fulfilled soon!
updates.update_content:
Dear backers
Thanks for your patience over the last week, we have been working hard to resolve issues surrounding the production allocation constraint of UP Squared Pentium 8GB RAM/128GB eMMC and they are all finally resolved!
We should be receiving them by next Wednesday and will carry on shipping at full speed... By the end of next week it should all be sent out and on its way to you guys!

Dearest backers
With so much of pleasure we are nearing the end of our Kickstarter shipments and should be complete tomorrow! Shipments are piled up to the ceiling in our delivery room and we are moving fast, all so that you can get your UP Squared as quickly as possible and begin your new project! 
However, there has been an unexpected delay today and for some reason the production of UP Squared 8GB/128GB has a delay; therefore we didn’t receive the shipment on time as expected.

updates.update_userinfo: UP accessories take UP² to the next level!

updates.update_content:
Hello guys!
We have some news to share on the progress of shipments.
Those of you who have chosen an UP Squared Kickstarter version with ABS Chassis, we have great news for you. We've just completed all the shipments today and you will receive the tracking no. notification very soon! Please check your emails for this number.

MrT, I own both versions. The up-core is a revision or so behind square, which means that Intel has improved or re-engineered the silicon to enable more functionality, less power usage, sometimes higher clock speeds, or a smaller die with room for more and/or faster cache. The squared-version has a bigger overall footprint, the addition of PCI-E lanes and higher-clockspeeds with more room for temporary and long term storage. If you are just beginning to tinker, the squared is easier to get started with. If you want a standard size, that will fit many of the Raspberry Pi Cases available, the the original Up is a great platform.

@Mihail: you can find self powered multi-discs (from 2 up to 8 disks) enclosures for 3.5 HDD with both USB3 and eSATA interface. Note that if you want to use the eSATA you will need to know for sure that either the on-board SATA port on the UP2, or your mPCIe SATA card, supports SATA port multiplier, otherwise you will see only one disk. If using the USB3 interface, well it acts as a normal USB3 hub so no problem.
@Mihail: Absolutely. I can see people wanting to build a cheap VM park wanting such a solution as well.

I still think the idea of an addon "12v power board" with a DC-DC converter for 5v and FET gates power the HDD power is quite good and something that the UP team can explore later on. It would make a great pair with the mPCIe -> SATA adapter they mention.

@Mihail: To clarify, what I mean with different target audience than the UP Squared is that the UP Squared is designed to be a self-powered low power device, and that if you want to do something that requires more then that needs solving. The TK1's audience is "power everything from the TK1 itself", that's why the max draw is 4.6A@12V from the whole thing, including peripherals.
No matter which way you go it's obviously not as easy as if 12V was available on the UP Squared but that was a design decision they made, but on the UP and on the UP Squared.

Plus having a 12v PSU for the board won't be much of a solution as far as how many drives you want to plug thus how many Amps you will draw ..powering the drives externally seems a better/safer solution eliminating the risk of damaging the board's power circuits....

Btw, I have a Nvidia Jetson TK1 board. It's powered by 12v and has a standard ATX Molex connector for the SATA hdd. This makes life quite a lot easier in this aspect. Of course it's a much bigger board. So out of curiosity I decided to dig into the board schematics. It turns out the 12v for the HDD is taken directly from the 12v board input, but gated using one of the GPIO pins on the main CPU and a couple of FETs. I was thinking it would be possible to do something similar and use a 12v power supply, but I would need to do my own 12v to 5v DCDC step down for the UP main power. Really not something I'm prepared to do on my own.

@Bartek (this is my own personal experience) eMMC is generally faster then uSD and slower then SSD, especially in multiple small operations. eMMC uses essentially the same flash chips as SSD (though SSD usually use a bit higher quality) but SSD has alot of supporting hardware like dedicated controllers and cache that eMMC lacks. If you are looking for maximum data speed you will wand to look into a mSATA or SATA3 SSD. eMMC should be fine for most stuff, but you may notice a slightly less snappy experience.

@ Stefan Smietanowski - Absolutly agree. Two cases make sense. A narrow one an one that allows adding storage and / or shields via the 40 PINs.
@UP: Another way is to actually replace 1 HDMI with 1 DP (Mini-DP).

@Christian: Personally I'd say if they make a case with room for HDD/SDD, then it would be a separate model, ie two cases. I want an as small one as possible, others may want a larger one (like yourself).

@UP I can only speak for myself but if you would be replacing the existing HDMI 1.4b's with DP 1.2a, I'd say replace both. If it is, as you say, an expansion board, I would say 1 is enough. I would still consider replacing the HDMI's with DP's though. Adapters are cheap and there are small ones available. Just the dynamic of being able to go further with the boards (which is to me one of the awesome ideas of the UPs) shouldn't be limited by using a connector standard that is less powerful than what the solution can do. In my opinion of course. DP 1.2a can be converte to HDMI 2.0, but HDMI 1.4b can't be converted to DP 1.2a (full spec).

btw, any stretch goals planned? Like including a mPCI-E SSD or the case? Also regarding the case please incl. space for HDDs / SSDs. Ideally with a short or even propriatary SATA cable or SATA/Power cable that goes to a port where one attaches his disk to Similar to a disk port in a server or NAS.

@UP I also would like to see onboard PINs that allows stacking of a UPS shield and connecting it directly to the board. Or can the 40-PIN Raspberry Headers provide such feature? Basically similar to the Raspberry UPS shields with LiPo batteries. Also, in that regard a more general question - is the board layout final?
Will an active heat sink option available just like the original UP Board did?

Apollo Lake has, as far as I can see, DP 1.2a, and, as bernstein pointed out - 1.4b. Apollo Lake however, correct me please if you find other information, lacks HDCP. That could be a reason for not including DP but staying with HDMI. Kaby Lake has HDCP 2.2 but I'm not seeing it in the info I'm reading for Apollo Lake.
@bernstein That is interesting, I just realized it will do 4k at 30hz, but that is kinda pointless IMO. I am fine with 1080p. @UP, will Up2 support 1080p 120Hz?
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DisplayPort#Resolution_and_refresh_frequency_support_for_DisplayPort
And a DP (which does 3840x2160@60Hz) can be adaptered to a HDMI 2.0 (which also does 3840x2160@60Hz) but HDMI 1.4b with an adapter still won't do 3840x2160@60Hz.

@Stefan Smietanowski Most boards in this space only have a single HDMI port, I am just glad to see two finally. and it is not as if HDMI to DP converters don't exist. Would have been nice to see HDMI 2.0 and 4K support though.
Also, from my point of view regarding the Why-not-use-DP-instead-of-HDMI : If space is an issue, mini-DP solves the space issue.
FPGA firmware will be open source ?

Can you briefly explain the Innovator packages? Specifically, "the best contributors will get a new UP² when we start the mass production." Is this about the best/useful projects we can design, or is this about ways we can fully test the board?
@UP You may not have an answer, but how close to final is the basic board layout? are dimensions and hole placement etc likely to change?
I would have to second bernstein here, anyone can buy an adapter from DP to HDMI 2.0, but a HDMI 1.4b port is limited to 30Hz @ 4096x2160, regardless of adapter used.
Can you clarify on the innovators package what is meant by the best contributors will receive a new board after the testing period? How does that work?
How hot would the CPU get when at its full swing?
@UP Maybe you bundle with a mPCI SATA SSD like the Kingdisk SSD-KD-SMP-MJ5 or a Adapter like shown here: http://www.hwtools.net/Adapter/M2MS1.html
3. Lost the link/reference, but read that the UP2 is compatible with linux mint... Do you mean mint 18.0?

@UP Same question as Christian, a good 3D model of at least the outer dimensions of the board (once it is finalized) maybe in a couple of formats (.dwg, .skp, .stl etc.) would be a welcome addition. Though of course as I learned with my UP 3D printed case, nothing quite substitutes for a board in hand with a calipers. Looking forward to playing with the most powerful mini-PC yet.
@UP can you share the board measurements to allow development of 3D printed cases?
Can we use the M.2 socket to install a SSD or can the PCIe port be used for a SSD?
Hi, Can you give exact reference for MAX10 component, and the connections to the processor ?
Also, any chance you can offer a version with the Celeron N3450?
Hi, for the product only reward, can we just purchase the power supply separately in your store and have it shipped with the board once they are ready to ship?
Can the board be shipped from Europe (due to customs)?
I second @Alexandre KELLER on the need for a multiple units pledge. In my case different versions of the UP^2 rather multiple of the same kind.
The passive heatsink will be able to cool the 6W TDP (outside a case at least) for 24/7 full power?
Great, i am in :-)
Keep on going the g00d w0rk!
Will there be a chassis available for the up square?
The Original UP project does not even have a working android release yet and here you are with another project promising android SUPPORT.

campaign.story:
From push buttons to e-panels, the development of technology keeps improving the way we interact with our surroundings. Since the advent of voice interaction technology, our life has truly become easier in many ways.
We think we can take advantage of this technology, and achieve more with it – ReSpeaker provides an open source, modular voice interface that allows us to hack things around us, just using our voices.
Rather than a voice assistant that fulfills simple tasks only when you asked, ReSpeaker provides a hands-free way of voice interaction for you and your surroundings. 
With ReSpeaker, you are able to control, or even communicate with your toy robot, your home appliances, your plant, your office, your internet-equipped devices and many other things in your daily life.
More detail about the Stretch Goal 1 please go to: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/seeed/respeaker-an-open-modular-voice-interface-to-hack/posts/1663367
More detail about the Stretch Goal 2 please go to: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/seeed/respeaker-an-open-modular-voice-interface-to-hack/posts/1679978
Powered by the MT7688 Wi-Fi module and the built-in high performance microphone, ReSpeaker responds to your voice and recognize your speeches based on powerful online cognitive services like Microsoft Cognitive Service, Amazon Alexa Voice Service, Google Speech API, Wit.ai and Houndify.
Also with the on board SD card slot to extend the storage and the integrated lightweight speech recognition engine - the PocketSphinx, ReSpeaker works equally well for keywords spotting when offline. You can have a large vocabulary and audio files stored in local storage to implement the speech recognition at anytime, anywhere, even without the internet.
Setting up ReSpeaker is super easy and only takes a few minutes.
Without any App installation, you can start by connecting ReSpeaker to your WiFi network and then directly use our Web-based App to access a range of rich featured applications that ReSpeaker has provided, includes music streaming, file manager, plug-in, customized settings and more.
Voice interface has never been apart from music entertainment, so does ReSpeaker. 
ReSpeaker supports Airplay/DLNA for wireless music streaming. Just connect ReSpeaker to any ordinary speaker with an AUX cable, then you can start enjoying the music you love without pressing a single button.
Of course we want to explore more possibilities coming out from ReSpeaker, and to achieve that we believe the best way is to leverage the power of the open source community. ReSpeaker runs the OpenWrt system that is based on Linux, which makes it 100% friendly to developers. 
And provided with our detailed and easy-to-use SDK, developers are able to develop more applications using Python on Linux. ReSpeaker also supports other popular programming languages like C/C++, Arduino, JavaScript and Lua.
ReSpeaker is not limited to what it can do for now, it is always growing. We’ve developed a plug-in system that would continuously expand ReSpeaker’s features and functionalities in the future. 
Our team will keep adding more plug-ins for ReSpeaker to cover as many things as possible that people want to have voice interactions with. 
Advanced users can also develop their own plug-ins using our user-friendly Python APIs. All the plug-ins will be shared on the Web APP and free-to-download for everyone.  
In addition to the plug-in system, ReSpeaker is also extendable with plug-n-play hardware add-ons. 
The far-field MIC Array allows your ReSpeaker to be able to recognize your location and hear you from across the room even while the music is playing. 
And the Grove extension board brings even more possibilities as you can connect various Grove sensors and actuators to extend its capabilities. The two onboard expansion headers also offer I2S, I2C, AUX, USB 2.0, GPIOs and many other interfaces that you can use for more applications.
You might wondering why ReSpeaker does not have speaker. In fact it does. We've cooperated with Meow King Audio Electronic Company and develop the Meow King Drive Unit. It can be directly connected to the bottom of ReSpeaker Core to produce beautiful sound out of it.
All the add-ons are modularized and have an identical disk design same as the core board. They can be stacked to one another when they are connected through soldering-free pins and header.
To improve the voice interaction experience, we developed the ReSpeaker Mic Array based on the XVSM-2000 Smart Microphone from XMOS. The board integrates 7 PDM microphones to help enhance ReSpeaker's acoustic DSP performance to a much higher level. With the Mic Array attached onto the top of the ReSpeaker Core, the Core is now able to: 
Hear You From Far Away
Focus On Your Voice
 Improve Your Voice Quality
The exposed PCB design does not mean ReSpeaker is just for people who knows a lot about hardware or software. 
The plug-in system is designed for the community to share and download their voice interactive projects as a simple plug-in to the ReSpeaker module. It has significantly simplified the use of ReSpeaker as anyone who has a ReSpeaker can install the plug-ins they want with a single click, and after that they can run voice interaction just like any others. 
Developers can of course achieve more with the SDK we provide to develop their own voice interaction projects .
For beginners, we have step-by-step tutorials and recipes to help you getting started with your first project with ReSpeaker.
Rather than the on board MT7688 Wi-FI module which runs the Linux based OpenWrt, ReSpeaker is also powered by the ATmega32u4 chip and it’s absolutely Arduino compatible, which means, we can use ReSpeaker as a powerful Arduino board and do many ‘Arduino’ things. It’s for learning, it’s for practicing, and it’s for fun.
For example, you can program it with Arduino IDE to have a special DIY piano that is built on 8 cherry tomatoes connecting to the 8 touch sensors of ReSpeaker.
We are making ReSpeaker compatible with our previous project the Wio Link and the subsequent members of the Wio family the Wio Node and the Wio Core.
Wio Link is an ESP8266 based open-source Wi-Fi development board to create IoT applications by virtualizing plug-n-play Grove modules to RESTful APIs with mobile APPs. 
More information about Wio Link can be either find at our previous Kickstarter Campaign :
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/seeed/wio-link-3-steps-5-minutes-build-your-iot-applicat/description
or at Wio Link's official website:
http://iot.seeed.cc/
There are videos demonstrate what is Wio Link and how easy it is to build an Internet of Things application with Wio Link,
How exactly does ReSpeaker works with the Wio Link/Node/Core?
The introduction of the Wio family has truly brought what ReSpeaker can do to a higher level. 
To user ReSpeaker with Wio, simply pair your ReSpeaker to your Wio product using our Web App, then you can have a voice interaction with any of your IoT devices that is built on Wio. Like voice control your Pet Feeder built with Wio to dispense treats, or ask your Wio based Smart Plant if she need some water. 
Check out the following demoes to see the VOICE INTERACTION BETWEEN YOU AND...
For each ReSpeaker Core reward it also comes with a 8G Class 10 Micro SD Card. 
 ReSpeaker Core Module
- AI7688 Wi-Fi Module
Operation system: GNU/Linux based OpenWrt
Wi-Fi Network: Support Legacy 802.11b/g and HT 802.11n modes  
Expansion: Two expansion headers for I2C, GPIO and USB 2.0 host 
Interfaces: Built-in 3.5mm AUX port, Micro USB and SD card slot 
- ATMega32U4 Coprocessor  
USB CDC virtual serial port for linux console
12 programmable RGB LED indicators  
8 on board touch sensors
- Codec WM8960
DAC SNR 98dB (‘A’ weighted), THD -84dB at 48kHz, 3.3V  
ADC SNR 94dB (‘A’ weighted), THD -82dB at 48kHz, 3.3V  
Stereo Class D Speaker Driver with 87% efficiency (1W output)  
On-chip Headphone Driver  
40mW output power into 16Ω at 3.3V  
THD -75dB at 20mW, SNR 90dB with 16Ω load  
On-chip PLL provides flexible clocking scheme  
Sample rates: 8, 11.025, 12, 16, 22.05, 24, 32, 44.1, 48 kHz
- Power Supply: 5V DC  
- Dimensions: 70mm diameter  
- Weight: 17g


Mic Array
XMOS microcontroller with 16 cores inside  
7 high performance digital microphones
Supports Far-field Voice Capture (up to 10m)
Supports Beamforming, Acoustic Source Localization, Nosie Suppression, De-reverberation and Acoustic Echo Cancellation
12 programmable RGB LED indicators  
Microphones: ST MP34DT01-M  
Sensitivity: -26 dBFS (Omnidirectional)  
Acoustic overload point: 120 dBSPL  
SNR: 61 dB  
Power Supply: 5V DC from Micro USB or expansion header  
Dimensions: 70mm (Diameter)  
Weight: 15.25g
Grove Extension Board
Grove Ports: 10
Digital I/Os: 3
Analog I/Os: 4
I2C Interface: 2
UART: 1
Dimensions: 70mm (Diameter)
Weight: 15.25g
Meow King Drive Unit
Rated Power: 5W
Impedance: 4Ω
SNR: ≥ 75dBA
Sensitivity: 550 ± 50mV
Degree of Distortion: ≤ 0.5% 
Frequency Response: 85Hz - 20kHz
Power Supply: 5V through USB or through 3.7V, 1500mAh battery
Speaker Diameter:  40mm
Seeed has always been an open Source hardware innovation platform from the very beginning. We focus on providing easy-to-use open hardware products that acts as tools for makers to build viable prototype at very low development costs. 
The neat modular design makes sure that ReSpeaker has a highly customizable appearance and limitless DIY possibilities. You can wrap it up with your own remarkable designs based on 3D printing, laser cutting, CNC or injection molding, and add it into your voice controlled project for prototyping. 
If you wanna go further, the Seeed Fusion Prototyping Service can help redesign and optimize your prototype into a more integrated version without too much investment, and even help you complete small batch production from up to 10k pieces with Seeed Propagate Service. 
Your audio based projects can also benefit from our Mic Array HDK by integrating its rich features like Far-field Voice Capture and Beamforming etc into it.
In any case, Seeed is happy to help promote your product though our online & offline channels as well as social media.
To find more information please visit http://www.seeedstudio.com/propagate/
Seeed has helped many successful Kickstarter projects for productization, you can find a full list of them at https://www.kickstarter.com/pages/seeed
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
We made 3 versions to improve the product experiencing and extend the functionality . Currently the product is under CE, FCC certificating and closely software developing. The production will be kicked off right after the campaign is completed and we anticipate to ship all the rewards Nov, 2016. And our trustful family member — Agile Manufacturing Center will help fulfil all the quality and quantity requirements on time.

International Logistics

We're proud to have Seeed fans in over 200 countries. We have shipped our products worldwide since 2008. If shipping issues come up, our expert logistics team will help solve problems and deliver Respeaker onto your hands. Please note that you may be responsible for duties, fees and taxes applicable to your region.

Forecasting risk

We’ve done our very best to forecast demand and create a solid production plan with our Agile Manufacturing Center. We’ve dealt with lots of manufacturing projects successfully from Kickstarter and we believe we can handle unexpected events.

Technical support

If you have questions at any time, during or after the campaign has closed, you can always reach us at support.seeedstudio.com/.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_content:
Hey Backers!
Short update, and possibly the last. First sorry for the delay, we wanted to wait until we had the documentation prepared. We have sent out all of the Meow King Drive Units along with the 2-Mic HATs. If you want to purchase a MKDU (or ReSpeaker Unit, as they are also known) we will have them on Seeed Bazaar soon, after we know most of the backers have received theirs.
Documentation for the Meow King Drive Unit can be found here! It will include how to update the firmware of the ReSpeaker Core to make it compatible with the MKDU.

TL;DR: Hi. Finishing the final units, expect to ship by end of week w/2-Mic HAT. Seeed is going on vacation for a week. Will post next update 10/10ish. Bye.
Ni Hao! We produced 250 unit in the last week, bringing the total finished units to 300. Attached you will find some photos of the assembly run. The remaining 200 are being assembled as I write this update. We expect to be shipping the Meow King Drive Units starting Wednesday, but definitely by Thursday. These will include the ReSpeaker 2-Mics Pi HAT, as well.
The shipments will be delivered by the following services: EU Post: Netherlands, France, Spain, Italy USPS: United States, Australia, United Kingdom, Germany, Israel SF Express: China HK LOCAL: Hong Kong Singapore Post: others

Hey backers! We were hoping to get a few production photos to share, but they will not begin production until Friday. Up until Friday the factory will be producing other products. The work on the Meow King Drive Unit is mostly paperwork and preparing supplies. Since we do lack some photos here, we will have photos of production in the next update. Last week we got all 50 Meow Kings Drive Units assembled - previously we had only assembled about 5, and tested the remaining 45 unit’s electrical and physical components. We used these 50 to learn the best method for testing and assembly so we can reduce overall production time come Friday. With this step finished, we have the green light for full production. 

Also, since it has been pointed out that it’s Tuesday, China time, when we are releasing these posts, I will say all future updates will be posted on Tuesdays, China time. I like to have our US employee double check my grammar, and I’d rather not ask her to work on her Sundays.

Dear Backers,
Our test engineers have approved the Meow King Drive Unit for production! We will ship these out by the end of day, September 30, 2017. We will be posting weekly updates on Mondays, including photos from the factory, until all the products have shipped. In addition, next week, hopefully with the Monday update, we will have a video showing the Meow King Drive Unit working, and go over the features.

updates.update_userinfo: ReSpeaker Ultimate (Plus) Will Be Shipped in Batches Starting from This Week
updates.update_content:
Dear Backers,  
We are sincerely sorry to inform you that, Meow King Drive Unit is still under production, we are afraid we need to delay it to July. 
We understand that the mistake was on our end.  As a result of this issue, we decided to ship the rewards in batches.

updates.update_userinfo: ReSpeaker Ultimate (Plus) Will Be Shipped Soon in June
updates.update_content:
Hi everyone.
Over the past few months, we’ve put so many efforts on the optimization of ReSpeaker Ultimate(Plus) to get the best result as we expected. After running various kinds of tests again and again, we’ve redesigned the ReSpeaker Ultimate(Plus) twice and actually developed three versions out of it. Each time we redesign the product, we’ve been able to make a significant improvement on it.

updates.update_userinfo: Shipment Info Update & Getting Started with ReSpeaker
updates.update_content:
Dear Backers,
Hi! We hope you all have a great new year!
Since we came back from the Chinese Spring Festival, we start keeping busy on the ReSpeaker shipment right away. The first round of shipment (exclude the ReSpeaker Ultimate and ReSpeaker Ultimate Plus) will be done in the end of this month (Feb 2017). However, due to the Chinese New Year, some of our suppliers just come back to work this week, which may cause some delay to the shipment of ReSpeaker Ultimate and ReSpeaker Ultimate Plus, the expected delivery time is in April 2017. The whole group is working hard to push this and we are trying our best to get ReSpeaker on your hand as soon as possible.

updates.update_userinfo: Happy New Year & Updates for ReSpeaker Shipments
updates.update_content:
Dear Backers,
Happy New Year!
After reworked, the ReSpeakers are working well and till now half of the rewards have been shipped out (exclude the ReSpeaker Ultimate and ReSpeaker Ultimate Plus).  
Soon we'll send you the tracking numbers via Kickstarter Message, please pay attention to check your message inbox.

Dear Backers,  
We are sincerely sorry to inform you that, during our last round of Quality Test, we found some of the LED components on the PCBs have been subjected to damp. Consequently, in order to ensure the quality of the product, all the ReSpeaker Cores and ReSpeaker Mic Arrays have been send back to rework, and the shipment of our first batch of ReSpeakers will be delayed to the end of December.

Steve

Thank you! I've downloaded/installed the example to the core board and will test it over the weekend.
Best regards

campaign.story:
Check out our Podcast interview on Art of the Kickstart!
     Introducing ZEEQ, the world’s most sophisticated pillow. ZEEQ is not just another device or accessory, it is an active participant in your sleep. ZEEQ can play music to help you fall asleep, monitor and react to your snoring, analyze your sleep and intelligently wake you up. Unlike other sleep technology ZEEQ actually responds to the data it collects.
    ZEEQ will help you fall asleep by allowing you to listen to music through the pillow and letting you choose music from your favorite sources. You can set a sleep timer in the app so the music will stop automatically - that way you can focus on sleep. We have even created some new relaxing tracks (some even using binaural beats) to help you fall asleep faster and achieve even more restful sleep.
If ZEEQ hears snoring, it will gently vibrate the pillow to encourage a new sleeping position. 
Your natural sleep movements are recorded and used to wake you up at the ideal moment in your sleep cycle, making groggy mornings a thing of the past. Most importantly, ZEEQ is the most comfortable pillow you will ever own. 
 All the technology in the world will never be more important than softness, support, and premium materials, but luckily ZEEQ integrates technology and comfort seamlessly.
Make sleep a priority no matter your lifestyle. ZEEQ integrates into your existing sleep habits and improves your sleep without you even being aware of it.  
 ZEEQ links to a smartphone app, so you can see your sleep data, including your Snore Score. If you want to take it a step farther, the app can help you track your diet, exercise and other habits to analyze how these factors effect your sleep, so you can make changes toward more restful slumber.
                The ZEEQ Difference
The ZEEQ pillow will improve your sleep quality and quantity in multiple ways.
If you fall asleep better with music, REM-Fit Audio lets you stream music wirelessly, so you don’t have to sleep with headphones in and you won’t disturb your partner. You can even use one of the REM-Fit soundscapes if you prefer a more ambient experience.
PLAY

The Snore Alarm uses a built in microphone with decibel sensitivity to hear snoring, and responds by gently vibrating the pillow to encourage the user to change positions without waking them up. 
PLAY

As soon as you go to bed, ZEEQ will start to monitor your sleep. It uses a 3-axis gyroscope to detect your motion throughout the night and provide data on the quality of your sleep.
PLAY

Smart Wake senses where you are in your sleep cycle based on these movements, and wakes you up at the ideal moment in a predetermined time range. It will use soft vibrations to wake you gently without affecting your partner. 
PLAY

Most importantly, ZEEQ is the most comfortable pillow you will ever own. REM-Fit is an expert in pillows and bedding, and will never sacrifice comfort for technology. A cozy, supportive memory foam shell and soft, durable Tencell pillow case make this pillow a dream to lay your head on. 
PLAY

_________________________________________________________________

Fall asleep effortlessly, sleep peacefully and wake up rejuvenated.
Aren’t you ready to see how it feels to be rested and energized for the two thirds of your life that you spend awake?
    The ZEEQ App
ZEEQ integrates with a smartphone app to deliver sleep and snore data. You can use as few or as many of ZEEQ’s features as you want, and you can customize each one to your preference. 

Want to turn down the vibration strength of your pillow?
Want to listen to Spotify as you fall asleep? 

All this and more can be controlled from the ZEEQ app. 
 See your 7 day trends on the app's dashboard. Find out how well you fared on sleep quality and snore score.
ZEEQ is an active participant in your sleep, and if you want to be an active participant too you can use the manual features provided in the app such as diet, caffeine and alcohol consumption, exercise tracking and more. 
 As the app learns more about your habits, both while asleep and while awake, it can detect patterns and correlations and start to make suggestions on how to improve your sleep quality.
  Bonus Rewards
When you back either of our Bonus Pack reward levels, you will receive one or more REM-Fit Activity Trackers. The activity tracker is the perfect compliment to your ZEEQ pillow because it tracks your activity during the day while ZEEQ monitors your sleep, and they both use the same app for integrated information.
Features:
• Track your steps, distance and calories burned
• ActivePoints - ActivePoints reward you for more than just your steps by analyzing the intensity and duration of your activity. The more active you are in a day, the more ActivePoints you can earn. 
• 360 LifeScore - Strive for a great night of sleep and a day of activity. Your SleepPoints and ActivePoints contribute to an overall 360 LifeScore.
Specifications
  Dimensions: 21”x 27”, the standard pillow size 
Materials: Tencel pillowcase, memory foam outer shell, comfort filling 
Battery: 5000 mAh rechargeable, lasts approximately 1 week
Electronics: 3-Axis gyroscope, vibration motors, individual decibel tuned microphone, 8 precision placed speakers
Reward Levels
     Project Development 
All the heavy lifting is done; we are already near completion on our design and engineering. We have several functional samples of the pillow. We already have manufacturers for all our components and have visited the factories in Shenzhen, Shanghai and India 8 separate times.
  There are a few big steps left to take: tooling, international testing and manufacturing. Your support will help us produce our first order of ZEEQ!
The good news for supporters is that the wait for the finished product will be short - you will have ZEEQ under your head in less than 6 months!
Timeline
 Get Your Project Funded Today!
www.funded.today/get-more-pledges 
About the Company 
PLAY


REM-Fit is a team of dedicated individuals who believe in a restful night’s sleep. 
Being fitness enthusiasts, we know how important rest and recovery are to any training routine, which is why we developed the first Total Sleep Recovery product line to help you meet your fitness goals.
Launched in 2014, REM-Fit is an active lifestyle bedding brand that that helps you achieve a healthy and active lifestyle by getting the best sleep possible for maximum recovery and comfort. The REM-Fit product line consists of three product categories: The REST, the ENERGIZE and the MOTIVATE Collections.
By focusing on both activity and the sleep needed for recovery, REM-Fit Active is an exciting way for you, no matter what fitness level, to track your sleep and activity and contribute to living a healthy lifestyle.
REM-Fit is a division of Protect-A-Bed, a company with over 35 years of experience in the sleep industry and more than 8000 stores across the country.
campaign.risks:
Risks and challenges
PILLOW COMFORT:
A pillow is a very personal item and people have different options on the ideal pillow. We have worked hard to make a pillow that will be very comfortable for all types of sleeping positions and firmness preferences.

MAKING EVERYTHING WORK TOGETHER:
There are a lot of sensors and components inside of a very soft object. Not only must if feel great to sleep on, it has to work properly. The noise sensors must react properly; the vibration motors must be strong enough to be felt through the padding, but not overpowering. We had to write new algorithms and logic so that all of our various components worked in concert with each other easily and effectively. 

DECIBEL READING:
Having a microphone that can detect sound down to a specific decibel and then react properly is a key component. The microphone has to be cost effective, sensitive and accurate. This is not an easy feat!

APP LOGIC:
With all the information coming from the pillow, the app needs to not only read the raw data, but present it in a way that makes sense to the end user. Also, the app must be easy to use, which can be a challenge with all the features available to the user.

MANUFACTURING:
We have already done all the heavy lifting: We have factories lined up, components sourced and functional prototypes created. However, we know that there can be unforeseen challenges between pre-production and production. It is not unheard of for a factory to change hands or a component to fail in production. We are an established company with experience and relationships, which should minimize any manufacturing issues we might face.
Learn about accountability on Kickstarter

updates.update_userinfo: ZEEQ version 1.25 is out now for iPhone and Android
updates.update_content:
Hello again everyone!
We hope you have all been enjoying your ZEEQ pillows and having a great 2017 so far.
An updated version of the ZEEQ app just hit the Google Play store as the Apple App store. Please be sure to update your ZEEQ app to get the latest and most stable build.  We have some pretty cool additions in this version as well as some bug fixes and stability improvements.
This release introduces in-app support chat, Russian language support (more languages coming soon!), a redesigned help and FAQ section in the app, and more.

Hello All!
Warrick and I are just now back from a loooooong trip. Our month started out in Las Vegas for CES, then off to China to sort out the remaining ZEEQ shipments and then back to CES for the Las Vegas Furniture Market to show off ZEEQ.  We have each been on 14 flights this month, so we are quite happy to be home.
Anyway, here is an update on shipping:

updates.update_userinfo: Updates on Shipping, Apps and CES (and Alexa integration)
updates.update_content:
Hello again everyone!!!
Warrick and I are in China and have some shipping updates, app updates as well as some fun info from CES.
Shipping:
There are about 300 people who have not yet received their ZEEQ orders.
Hello everyone!

Hello All! 
  We hope you have all been enjoying the holidays and your new ZEEQ pillow! While the majority of you are not having any issues with ZEEQ, we want to make sure that no one has any issues. We have set up 24/7 chat support over the holiday break to give you quick support with ZEEQ at REM-Fit.com - and that will be the FASTEST and BEST way to get support. The team on chat can look into your issue and hopefully get you up and running in no time. In some cases, we need your ZEEQ username so we can deeply investigate the issue, and the chat team will be the best to handle that for you.

Hello Backers!
I know it has been a while since we have updated you. Let’s cover three topics you have been asking about: 
1. Shipping Update 
2. Adjusting your ZEEQ

Hello again ZEEQ backers!
We will begin shipping ZEEQ soon, so we will be locking the surveys tonight.  If you haven't filled in your survey, please do so tonight so we can make sure ZEEQ arrives to you on time.  If we don't have a survey from you by tonight we cannot guarantee your ZEEQ will ship before Christmas.
You can fill out your survey here: https://www.zeeq.backerkit.com

Hello All!
Warrick and I are back in China & India finalizing the ZEEQ packaging, visiting the factories, getting all the logistics prepared and fine tuning the ZEEQ app.  As of now we are still on track for a December delivery. We will keep you updated as the shipments begin to go out.
Also, it looks like over 85% of you have already filled out your ZEEQ Backerkit surveys - thank you!  If you haven't had a chance to fill it out, or have lost it, you can access you survey here:

Hello Backers!
Warrick and I are headed to China for the final ZEEQ production run!  We just had one stop to make before our flight to China - PEPECOM in San Francisco.  PEPCOM is a press event where we got to show off ZEEQ for a bunch of press and bloggers before the holiday.  We did some live demos for the press showing the music playing, snore vibrating and more.  The response was pretty great.

I don't usually write reviews, but here is a short one for anyone that is interested. It was very easy to get the pillow and app all set up. I was pretty surprised at the slickness of the app. I expected something a little less polished this early, but it is super easy to use and looks great. I used the sleep tracking on it last night and it seems to have worked well. I got a sleep score of 94, which I assume is good. I did not use the music as I didn't want to make too many changes at once, but I have played with that a little and it's pretty cool. I think I need to take a little of the stuffing out as I think it felt a little thick for me, but overall it was comfortable. The only thing that will take some getting used to is understanding all of the various codes the pillow gives by using blinking lights on the part that connects to the charger.
